t: Proverbs 19
Better*pn the poor whose walk is blameless than*ld a fool whose lips are perverse.
Desire*pn without knowledge is not good— how*ld much more will hasty feet miss the way!
A*pn person’s own folly leads to their ruin, yet*ld their heart rages against the Lord.*s
Wealth*pn attracts many friends, but*ld even the closest friend of the poor person deserts them.
A*pn false witness will not go unpunished, and*ld whoever pours out lies will not go free.
Many*pn curry favor with a ruler, and*ld everyone is the friend of one who gives gifts.
The*pn poor are shunned by all their relatives— how*ld much more do their friends avoid them! Though*pn the poor pursue them with pleading, they*ld are nowhere to be found.
The*pn one who gets wisdom loves life; the*ld one who cherishes understanding will soon prosper.
A*pn false witness will not go unpunished, and*ld whoever pours out lies will perish.
It*pn is not fitting for a fool to live in luxury— how*ld much worse for a slave to rule over princes!
A*pn person’s wisdom yields patience; it*ld is to one’s glory to overlook an offense.
A*pn king’s rage is like the roar of a lion, but*ld his favor is like dew on the grass.
A*pn foolish child is a father’s ruin, and*ld a quarrelsome wife is like the*ld constant dripping of a leaky roof.
Houses*pn and wealth are inherited from parents, but*ld a prudent wife is from the Lord.*s
Laziness*pn brings on deep sleep, and*ld the shiftless go hungry.
Whoever*pn keeps commandments keeps their life, but*ld whoever shows contempt for their ways will die.
Whoever*pn is kind to the poor lends to the Lord,*s and*ld he will reward them for what they have done.
Discipline*pn your children, for in that there is hope; do*ld not be a willing party to their death.
A*pn hot-tempered person must pay the penalty; rescue*ld them, and you will have to do it again.
Listen*pn to advice and accept discipline, and*ld at the end you will be counted among the wise.
Many*pn are the plans in a person’s heart, but*ld it is the Lord’s*s purpose that prevails.
What*pn a person desires is unfailing love; better*ld to be poor than a liar.
The*pn fear of the Lord*s leads to life; then*ld one rests content, untouched by trouble.
A*pn sluggard buries his hand in the dish; he*ld will not even bring it back to his mouth!
Flog*pn a mocker, and the simple will learn prudence; rebuke*ld the discerning, and they will gain knowledge.
Whoever*pn robs their father and drives out their mother is*ld a child who brings shame and disgrace.
Stop*pn listening to instruction, my son, and*ld you will stray from the words of knowledge.
A*pn corrupt witness mocks at justice, and*ld the mouth of the wicked gulps down evil.
Penalties*pn are prepared for mockers, and*ld beatings for the backs of fools.
